awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Making Space for Story-Based Tinkering to Scaffold Early Informal Engineering Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project responds to calls to increase children's exposure and engagement in STEM at an early age. With the rise of the maker-movement, the informal and formal education sectors have witnessed a dramatic expansion of maker and tinkering spaces, programs, and curricula. This has happened in part because of the potential benefits of tinkering experiences to promote access and equity in engineering education. To realize these benefits, it is necessary to continue to make and iterate design and facilitation approaches that can deepen early engagement in disciplinary practices of engineering and other STEM-relevant skills. This project will investigate how stories can be integrated into informal STEM learning experiences for young children and their families. Stories can be especially effective because they bridge the knowledge and experiences young children and their caregivers bring to tinkering as well as the conversations and hands-on activities that can extend that knowledge. In addition, a unique contribution of the project is to test the hypothesis that stories can also facilitate spatial reasoning, by encouraging children to think about the spatial properties of their emerging structures.
 
This project uses design-based research methods to advance knowledge and the evidence base for practices that engender story-based tinkering. Using conjecture mapping, the team will specify their initial ideas and how it will be evident that design/practices impact caregivers-child behaviors and learning outcomes. The team will consider the demographic characteristics, linguistic practices, and funds of knowledge of the participants to understand the design practices (resources, activities) being implemented and how they potentially facilitate learning. The outcome of each study/DBR cycle serves as inputs for questions and hypotheses in the next. A culturally diverse group of 300+ children ages 5 to 8 years old and their parents at Chicago Children's Museum's Tinkering Lab will participate in the study to examine the following key questions: (1) What design and facilitation approaches engage young children and their caregivers in creating their own engineering-rich tinkering stories? (2) How can museum exhibit design (e.g., models, interactive displays) and tinkering stories together engender spatial thinking, to further enrich early STEM learning opportunities? and (3) Do the tinkering stories children and their families tell support lasting STEM learning? As part of the overall iterative, design-based approach, the team will also field test the story-based tinkering approaches identified in the first cycles of DBR to be most promising.
 
This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. It will result in activities, exhibit components, and training resources that invite visitors' stories into open-ended problem-solving activities. It will advance understanding of mechanisms for encouraging engineering learning and spatial thinking through direct experience interacting with objects, and playful, scaffolded (guided) problem-solving activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The TALES (Tinkering and Learning Engineering Stories) Project, a collaboration among Chicago Children's Museum, Loyola University Chicago, Northwestern University and Roosevelt University, focused on how combining storytelling with hands-on tinkering activities can promote engineering learning and spatial thinking among young children and their caregivers. Over the course of the project, we investigated how various tinkering program designs and facilitation approaches might support families in creating fanciful and real-life stories to motivate and explain their problem-solving.  


Due to the pandemic, early programming and research took place in families’ homes. Following a videotaped introduction, a child and parent were observed via Zoom while engaging in a story-based tinkering project using objects, toys, and materials in their homes. The three home-based programs informed Tinkering Lab programming when Chicago Children's Museum reopened. Using a design-based research process, we varied the engineering challenges and story elements presented in different iterations of the tinkering programming. Each program centered on an engineering-rich tinkering task that involved designing something that could do something (e.g., move, fly, fit), along with opportunities for iterative testing and fixing. Most programs invited the families to build a tinkering project for a character (e.g., a small toy or the participating child) and to invent their characters’ motivations, the story’s setting, and a plot.  For example, in the "Here to There" program, children were asked to choose an item to move from a table (here) to the floor (there) and to offer an "important reason" for why it needed to be relocated. Other challenges involved developing an aircraft for a toy monster pilot to deliver a package, developing a functional playground ride for three physically different toys, designing a hat that will stay on the child during games, and safely moving a toy driver through a perilous landscape of light and shadows. 

Tinkering Lab is equipped with multiple cameras allowing consenting families to be recorded and interviewed. We also collected data from a nearby exhibit, Story Hub, that invites families to reflect on their museum experiences. 472 families with 4-10-year-old children (45% male, 55% female) participated in the research in Tinkering Lab exhibit at Chicago Children’s Museum (50% Caucasian, 14% Hispanic/Latine, 11% Asian, 6% Black). Another 238 families participated from their homes via Zoom (53% male children, 47% female; 43% Caucasian, 26% Hispanic/Latine, 8% Black, 8% Asian).  

During this project, we found that families who created stories during tinkering talked more about engineering during the activity, immediately after, and weeks later, compared to families who did not create stories (Acosta & Haden, 2023). Families who used toy characters in their activities engaged in more storytelling during tinkering (Ocular et al., 2024), made more connections to prior experiences, and used more spatial language when reflecting on their tinkering (Nyland et al., 2024) than families who did not use toy characters. Building on this finding, we designed programs with clear story frameworks, consisting of characters, settings, and problems, and these features further promoted families’ storytelling. One analysis aimed to unpack the mechanisms through which storytelling can support STEM learning processes. The analysis suggested that storytelling can engender emotional engagement in the tinkering activity, which thereby promotes STEM conversations (Aldrich & Haden, 2024). The association between storytelling and emotional engagement was stronger for girls than for boys.  

We further considered how various program design choices and adult-child interactions can further advance STEM learning in the context of story-based tinkering programs. Providing access to a wider variety of building materials was associated with increases in children’s hands-on engagement during tinkering, as well as children’s spatial language use during and after tinkering (Hurka et al., 2024). Moreover, parents’ autonomy-supportive STEM talk during tinkering was positively associated with children’s STEM talk, demonstrating the value of encouraging children’s independence and exploration (Aldrich & Haden, 2024).   
At Chicago Children’s Museum, we often observed families creating digital stories by taking photos and recording videos about their tinkering activities. This motivated a study in which we found that children who created digital stories during tinkering talked more about engineering immediately after tinkering, and remembered more about their experience weeks later, than children who did not create digital stories (Pagano et al., 2024). Ongoing work is revealing that digital storytelling may be more beneficial for children who are excited about using cameras, compared to children who do not have strong enthusiasm for cameras.  

his project highlights how a range of storytelling practices can advance engineering learning and spatial thinking during family tinkering activities in museums and at home. We have disseminated this work in multiple peer-reviewed journal articles, through presentations at psychology and education conferences, and practitioner programming guides and blog posts. Overall, this work provides valuable empirical results demonstrating the benefits of combining storytelling with informal STEM education opportunities for young children and their families.
